facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 408-409 of 1964 were filed by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 5, 1963 of the Rajasthan High Court in D.B. Civil Writ Petitions Nos. 172 and 111 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 408-409 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 5, 1963 of the Rajasthan High Court in D.B. Civil Writ Petitions Nos. 172 and III of 1961.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court allowed Civil Writ Petitions Nos. 111 and 172 of 1961 and quashed orders of Sales Tax authorities imposing penalties on respondent Ghasilal for delay in payment of tax due.

anchor.surface_text: C. Kosliwal, Advocate-General, for the State of Rajasthan, K. K. Jain and R. N. Sachthey, for the appellant. K. Garg, S. C. Aqarwala, D. P. Singh and M. K. Rama- murthi, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Sikri, J. These two appeals by special leave are directed against the judgment of the Rajasthan High Court allowing Civil Writ Petitions Nos. 111 and 172 of 1961, and quashing orders of the Sales Tax authorities imposing penalties on the respondent, Ghasilal, for delay in payment of tax due.

facts.text: Rajasthan Sales Tax Rules were published in the Rajasthan Gazette on March 28, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts are these. On March 28, 1955, Rajasthan Sales Tax Rules  hereinafter referred to as the Rules  were published in the Rajasthan Gazette.

facts.text: Rajasthan Sales Tax Act came into force on April 1, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The Rajasthan Sales Tax Act  hereinafter referred to as the Act  came into force on April 1, 1955.

facts.text: Respondent filed Civil Writ Petition No. 11 of 1958 in the High Court challenging assessments for 1955-56 on ground that Rules were invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed Civil Writ Petition, No. 11 of 1958, in the High Court challenging the making of assessments on the turnover of the respondent for the year 1955-56 on the ground that the said Rules were invalid.

facts.text: On January 9, 1958, High Court passed interim order that petitioner keep proper accounts, file prescribed returns but not be assessed till further orders.

anchor.surface_text: On January 9, 1958, the High Court passed an interim order that the petitioner will keep proper accounts and file the prescribed returns but he shall number be assessed till further orders.

facts.text: Ordinance No. 5 of 1959 was promulgated on November 6, 1959, validating the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: While the petition was pending in the High Court, an Ordinance  No. 5 of 1959  was promulgated on November 6, 1959, validating the Rules.

facts.text: Respondent withdrew Writ Petition No. 11 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the respondent withdrew Writ Petition No. 1 1 of 195 8.

facts.text: Rajasthan Sales Tax Validation Act (Rajasthan Act 43 of 1959) replaced the Ordinance on December 17, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: On December 17, 1959 the Rajasthan Sales Tax Validation Act  Rajasthan Act 43 of 1959  replaced the Ordinance.

facts.text: Effect of Ordinance and Act was to validate the Rules, even if defect existed; common ground between parties.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the effect of the said Ordinance and the said Act was to validate the Rules, even if any defect existed in the making of the Rules.

facts.text: Appellant states Ordinance and Validating Act enacted out of abundant caution.

anchor.surface_text: We may mention that according to the appellant, the said Ordinance and the said Validating Act were enacted out of abundant caution.

facts.text: On December 4, 1959, Sales Tax Officer, Kotah City Circle sent show cause notice to respondent stating writ dismissed on 23rd November 1959, deposit tax within a week.

anchor.surface_text: On December 4, 1959, the Sales Tax Officer, Kotah City Circle, sent a show cause numberice to the respondent in the following words Your writ No. 11 has been dismissed by the Honble High Court on 23rd November, 1959.

facts.text: Show cause notice served on respondent on December 4, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: This numberice was served on the respondent the same day.

facts.text: Respondent filed return for 4th quarter ending October 22, 1957 and deposited Rs. 11,898.31 as tax.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed a return for the 4th quarter ending October 22, 1957, and Rs. 11, 898.31 was deposited as tax.

facts.text: On January 8, 1960, March 5, 1960 and March 19, 1960, respondent deposited Rs. 28,607 as tax for four quarters October 23, 1957 to November 10, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on January 8, 1960, March 5, 1960 and March 19, 1960, he deposited Rs. 28,607 as tax in respect of the four quarters of the accounting period October 23, 1957 to November 10, 1958.

facts.text: Not clear from record whether respondent filed returns on January 8, March 5, March 19, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: It is number clear from the record whether he filed returns on these dates.

facts.text: On April 25, 1960, Sales Tax Officer made assessment for period November 3, 1956 to October 22, 1957 and imposed penalty of Rs. 400 under s.16(1)(b).

anchor.surface_text: On April 25, 1960, the Sales Tax Officer made an assessment in respect of the accounting period November 3, 1956 to October 22, 1957, and proceeded to impose a penalty of Rs. 400 under s. 16 1  b  of the Rajasthan Sales Tax Act.

facts.text: Respondent appealed to Deputy Commissioner Sales Tax (Appeals), Kotah, who dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent appealed to Deputy Commissioner Sales Tax  Appeals , Kotah, who dismissed the appeal, holding that the stay order of the High Court did number justify the respondent in number filing the return and depositing the tax

facts.text: On December 6, 1960, Sales Tax Officer assessed period October 23, 1957 to November 10, 1958 and imposed penalty of Rs. 1,000 for not depositing tax in time.

anchor.surface_text: On December 6, 1960, the Sales Tax Officer assessed the respondent in respect of the accounting period October 23, 1957 to November 10, 1958, and imposed a penalty of Rs. 1,000 for number depositing the tax in time on the same grounds.

facts.text: Respondent filed petition No. 111 of 1961 under Art. 226 on April 3, 1961 challenging penalty for November 3, 1956 to October 22, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then filed a petition  No. III of 1961  under Art. 226 of the Constitution, on April 3, 1961, challenging the imposition of penalty in respect of the period November 3, 1956 to October 22, 1957,

facts.text: Respondent filed petition No. 172 of 1961 on April 4, 1961 challenging penalty for October 23, 1957 to November 10, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: and on April 4, 1961, he filed a petition  No. 172 of 1961  challenging the imposition of penalty in respect of the up.65-5 accounting period October 23, 1957 to November 10, 1958.

facts.text: High Court allowed the writ petitions.

anchor.surface_text: As we have said before, the High Court allowed the petitions.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds no breach of s.16(1)(b), penalties cannot be sustained, appeals dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there has been numberbreach of s. 16 1  b  of the Act, and companysequently, the orders imposing the penalties cannot be sustained.

facts.text: No tax was due till respondent filed returns under s.7(1).

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Garg companytends that there was numberbreach of s. 16 1  b  of the Act. No tax was due till the respondent filed returns under S. 7 1  of the Act.

arguments.claim: No breach of s.16(1)(b) as no tax due within time allowed; tax due only after quantified by s.7(2) return or s.10 assessment
'Time allowed' in s.16(1)(b) meaning not decided as no tax was due anyway
Not concerned with breach of s.16(1)(c)

holdings.text: There has been no breach of s. 16(1)(b) of the Act, and consequently, the orders imposing the penalties cannot be sustained.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there has been no breach of s. 16 1  b  of the Act, and consequently, the orders imposing the penalties cannot be sustained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No tax was due until quantified by self-assessment under s.7(2) via return or by assessing authority under s.10; failure to pay tax due within time allowed requires tax to be due first.

holdings.text: Section 3 read with s.5 creates liability to pay tax (makes tax payable) but no tax can be said to be due under s.16(1)(b) until ascertained under s.10 or s.7(2).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Charging sections impose liability but 'due' requires quantification by assessment or return-based deposit.

holdings.text: Show cause notice dated December 4, 1959 does not make tax due under s.16(1)(b).
holdings.reasoning_summary: No provision or rule supports that a show cause notice creates tax as due; r.31 applies only post-assessment.

holdings.text: Stay order of High Court does not imply obligation to deposit tax under s.7(2) or breach s.16(1)(b).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Stay order requiring filing returns but no assessment does not imply pre-return deposit obligation, else useless; s.7(2) applies only on filing return.

holdings.text: No need to decide meaning of 'time allowed' in s.16(1)(b).

anchor.surface_text: There was some discussion before us as to the meaning of the words time allowed but we need not decide in this case whether the words time allowed connote time allowed by an assessing authority or time allowed by a provision in the Rules or the Act,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary as no tax was due anyway under s.16(1)(b).

holdings.text: Court not concerned with whether breach of s.16(1)(c).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Case turns on s.16(1)(b), not failure to furnish returns.

holdings.text: No opinion expressed on violation of Art.20(1) or validity of Rules.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court came to the conclusion that the penalties had been imposed in violation of Art. 20 1  of the Constitution, but it is not necessary to deal with this question because we are inclined to accept the contention... But we express no opinion one way or the other on these points

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appeals disposed on narrow statutory construction point.

holdings.text: No opinion expressed on procedural defect in Rules promulgation.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court was in error in holding that there has been contravention of Art. 20 1  of the Constitution, and that the Rules as originally published on March 28, 1955, suffered from no procedural defect... But we express no opinion one way or the other on these points

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary as decided on s.16(1)(b) interpretation.
